reviews.description: My family rode the North Pole Flyer, not so much for the Santa stuff since we have no children under 10, it was more for family fun. And it was a fantastic experience. The train was actually pretty cool, I've never been in a proper train before, I mean, it was old fashioned but still just a really really cool experience. We paid for the private suite and it was worth it, we also walked throughout the train which was a bit old west feeling. My favorite part was walking between cars to see the view unencumbered by windows.   We walked through all the cars (like most people on the train did) to see what the other cars were like. The giftshop car was the nicestest with big windows and plenty of room to walk around while balancing yourself on a rocking and rolling moving train.   Some of the private rooms give you an idea of what is was really like to ride a train across country with a sleeper car, teeny tiny shower, and narrow hallways. It was such a great experience.   Not sure why people complain about the views because mine were fantastic! I mean, c'mon. We live in Texas not Denver. I know what the hill country looks like. There's no mountains but where the hills meet the sky is expansive. It was beautiful.

reviews.author: Christina O.
reviews.description: Booked a sunset train ride for my husband and I and it was such a fun experience! We loved all the fun facts the volunteers had to share about the train cars and lifestyles of some of the riders back 100+ years. The sunset was magical and the night portion of the ride was really neat, having the moonlight illuminate the tracks in front of us. One of the cars is a dedicated gift shop/concession stand with a variety of alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverages to choose from. Everyone we came in contact with was so kind and made the experience that much more memorable. Overall such a great time - we would definitely book this experience again!

reviews.author: Roman H.
reviews.description: Their North Pole Flyer is like a joke. Don't waste your time and money, it is not worth it. Dirty cars, dirty seats, dirty windows with bleak scenery outside and Santa who gives a broken whistle. That is all for 2 hours trip. Even an obsessed with trains 4 years old was bored.  If you decide to go don't forget to take a mask or a respirator, it's hard to breathe inside because of dust.

reviews.author: Candice D.
reviews.description: We had a great time on the Beer Train last night that was advertised as a sunset tour that was 2.5 hours long.  Note that you have about 45 mins moving time, then 40 mins stopped for the engine to be brought from the back to the front and then 45 mins back again. You don't really see much of the sunset, and you aren't moving for 2.5 hours. They also assign seats ahead of time, some of the cars were nicer and louder than others, so just depends what you're looking for. The association was responsive on social media when I had questions, staff and crew on board were all very friendly. They dont really follow any of their own posted rules about masks, no personal coolers, etc. so just something to be aware of- but I think this also varied by car. Overall we had a great time and would go again!

reviews.author: Daniel P.
reviews.description: I'm pretty sure this is the tourism equivalent of chicken-and-waffles: another empty promise meant to separate me from my hard earned monies. Fortunately for me the plague was in top form. Was in the area looking for sustenance and 'Steam Train Association' showed on the map so I figured to pop in for a quick viddy before lunch. pulled up on a nearly empty lot, a shackled gate, and a locked door, the sign had the now common 'Closed for Plague' message which softened the blow of discovering "...that the train and rail yard are not open for public tours or photography" which meant the entirety of the museum was contained in the double-wide corner space in the strip. There's nothing inherently wrong with scenic train rides on vintage rolling stock, I've done it before and it's OK but that's just not my cup of meat. I was here for a bit of museuming but there was no museum to be had - nor postcarding nor touchable cars nor engines :-( sad face

reviews.author: Krystal S.
reviews.description: My husband and I went on the Hill Country Flyer for our anniversary weekend and we were in the "Rippling Stream" train car. The Train itself is quite impressive and was my first time on a real train not subway. The First Class Coach option was really nice and the seats were spread out along with social distancing, we felt really comfortable. My only complaint was it was VERY cold outside and though they are climate controlled, it was really cold the first half of the ride - coming back was much more comfortable. I also wished the lay over time perhaps had been 3 hours to provide a little more browsing time in Burnet. It would be cute to do music in each train car from the era the train was made. Ours was built in the late 30's so it would be a nice little touch that's simple to do! They had complimentary snacks and drinks which was a plus. Can't wait to do it again in a private suite!

reviews.author: Rebecca O.
reviews.description: Was a waste of money from Cedar Park to Burnet....was suppose to be Hill Country Flyer...saw no Hill Country...just a lot of brush blocking scenery....but not much of that either...Burnet was quaint...but will drive next time...big disappointment..

reviews.author: Allegre N.
reviews.description: This was an excellent experience. We took the train from Bertram to Burnet for one of the special events (Wedding Oaks wine trip). The staff was friendly and seemed very knowledgeable about the history of each train car. If you have a chance to walk to the very last car and look out the back, I definitely recommend taking in that view. I would have loved to take a longer trip and will look for other chances to ride.  The website is a little hard to use. We would have really liked a private cabin for our trip but didn't see how to book that on the website.   I wish the volunteer in our car would have been a little less Chatty Cathy when we weren't talking about the ride. It was a bit of a distraction from our enjoyment of the ride. Also, riding during COVID was a bit out of our comfort zone already so we were sad to see at least two volunteers wearing their masks covering only their mouth, not their mouth and nose. The website goes into great detail about precautions and that is a basic one not being taken. (That being said, they did a great job with social distancing and I felt like the train was very clean.)

reviews.author: Mike H.
reviews.description: Enjoyed my first ASTA experience today.  Here's my recap:  - Purchased a First Class Lounge ticket so I had my own room in Rippling Stream  - Train left the station on time, arrived at Burnet on time, and left for Cedar Park on time.   We were only an hour late reaching Cedar Park because a car thought it could outrun the train, but it could not.  Once the accident reporting was complete the train resumed.   - Personal note:  I am a train nerd and love riding trains, so my threshold of being annoyed on a train is higher than most.  This will affect my review below.    THE GOOD:  - clean cars, fun to walk in between them, and if you're without children, the adults only first class cars are a must - Rippling Stream and Nambe.   Otherwise with kids, I would recommend the Maurice Beckham or Eagle Cliff.    - the trip itself is smooth and the volunteers are friendly and helpful.  You can tell they enjoy being there, informing and helping others.     - Burnet has an abundance of antique shops if that's you're thing.  Also the soups at the downtown coffee shop are wonderful.     - The shootout show in Burnet, while not having a worry about winning any acting awards, is fun for the kids and has a good ending.  They could trim some of the fat from it, and make it a more concise / engaging story - there were a few too many awkward pauses.  But I applaud the folks who are likely doing this for free.  And the kids loved it.     THE NOT SO GOOD  - The scenic ride - if you're from the area this should not come as a shocker - is not that scenic.  There's a great bridge over the San Gab river but otherwise it's unremarkable trees, backyards, roads, and strip malls.    But again, none of this bothers me that much because I'm on a train relaxing.    - Burnet:  This is a sleepy, very conservative town.  One sign to deter thieves in a store said, "We got an alarm.  We got video.  We got guns.  DON'T BE DUMB."    While the downtown is a short walk from the train station, 2.5 hours here is way too much time unless you love antiques.   There isn't much else.   And as far as lunch goes, I highly recommend walking a bit farther past the first couple restaurants or else you'll have long wait times.   I went to a deli just a couple blocks away and it had no line.      - Announcements:  there are few.  Nothing along the way to alert you to landmarks or scenic opportunities (there is really just one, the bridge over the river).   But it would be nice to hear more than the pre recorded departure / arrival ones.    - The warm soft drinks:  no one wants green tea or apple juice at room temp.  There was literally an ice bucket next to these (but for scoping ice).  A second one to put these beverages on ice would go a long way.    - Lack of variety in snacks:  for a first class experience, at least more than the mini lemon cakes and mini cinnamon rolls would be nice.  Some savory, perhaps?   - chairs in the RS lounge car are what you'd find at your local dentist's waiting room.  I expected something that would at least remain comfy for 1.5 hours at a time.      OVERALL. - for the price I paid, it's 4/5 stars.  I knew the scenery wasn't going to awe, so most of my ranking is based on the train experience inside.  The quibbles above are all minor; chill the drinks, add some pretzels, get someone to donate an old leather chair or 2, and be a bit more chatty with us.    Those who really ranked their train ride low usually fall into the following categories, so please take them with a grain of salt:  - a/c sucked because it was Austin in the summer (hopefully fixable but not all that surprising) - solution is to go when it's not hot, the 60 days out of the year it's under 99 degrees.  I also think they have ironed out most of the a/c issues by now.    - Burnet was terrible, Burnet food was terrible, etc.  It's Burnet.  There's a reason it's not as well known as Fredericksburg.  You walk a bit father to get away from the crowds, you cross check their list of lunch spots they give you when you board  with a quick glance of Yelp reviews and you roll the dice.    - scenery sucked, super ghetto, etc.   Maybe because I grew up in St Louis, but using the word ghetto here is laughable at best.  It's junky, yes.  Unkempt, sure.   And truly, if you live in the region, you should know better than to expect breathtaking views.  You've driven on 183 east of 35?.  Same views.   If you're from out of town I could see valid point here since the website pushes it hard that it's scenic - but us locals know how much lipstick you can put on this pig.   So go check it out!  But go First Class if possible.  And be flexible about being home on time; like with any train, delays can happen.

reviews.author: Lori Ann L.
reviews.description: We rode the Hill Country Flyer which departs from the Cedar Park station and goes to Burnet, Texas,  where there is a two-hour layover so that passengers can disembark, do some shopping or grab some lunch or both.   Before leaving, the Burnet Gunfighters put on a show which is free to passengers, although they do accept donations.   The scenery leaves a lot to be desired, however that is not something that the Steam Train Foundation can control, they have a designated track and can not control who builds subdivisions or places gravel pits along the route.   If you are looking for a beautiful scenic ride, this probably isn't for you.  However, if you want to experience riding on a passenger train, and learning about the history of the railroads, it is a great experience.     They are very careful with social distancing and we felt completely safe riding the train.  I spoke with a couple of families that had young children and they loved it!   All in all, I would recommend it as a very enjoyable way to spend the day.

reviews.author: Peter D.
reviews.description: I rode the Sunset Express on 5-29-21 with my family, while on a trip to visit Austin. I'm from Southern California (this is important later). The scenery was certainly nice in some spots, but not enough. The sunset was awesome, but the experience wasn't that great. We paid for first class and rode aboard Eagle Cliff. Some basic drinks and snacks were provided, but the train was understaffed. No attendant for our car. One very sweet elderly volunteer was doing her best to handle two cars at once. I decided to offer to help, which she was very appreciative of. She said it was great that I wanted to help and so I did. I helped stock drinks and snacks as well as stocked ice to keep the drinks cold. Later on, a female volunteer who looked to be in her 40s came up to the counter said "Sir, you cannot be back there, what do you need?" I explained the situation, and she kind of had an attitude. I was informed in a rude tone that I had to be a member to help, and was given no thank you. Being that I live in Southern California, there's no way I could really be a member. While all this was happening, the AC in the car was doing a very poor job at keeping the car cold. It was unbearably hot in there, and everyone in the car was complaining. The excuse given was that the car is vintage and has a lot of runtime. The car was very original, and you could tell. That roughly translates to "we don't have the money or people to keep this car in tip top shape, and we don't have the money to upgrade it".  Eventually, my family was re-seated to the Rippling Stream. That was much better, but it didn't change the overall experience. Cherry on top was we were over an hour late returning to the Cedar Park station.   Not worth the money.

reviews.author: john g.
reviews.description: We also did the Xmas Polar Express train ride. Tickets were about $50 each. We also went with a friend and their kids too.   I'll give this train ride 4 stars. The kids were excited to see Santa and the ride was slow at times.   To start, one of the first things was a balloon guy. Ours was awesome. He was funny and overall entertaining. He had me laughing my @ss off.   Next came hot chocolate... it's hot chocolate.   After that was, singing Christmas Carols. They had 2 girls from McNeil high school. I felt sorry for them. They were nice, but they couldn't just get our car interested in singing.  A few of us sang, but overall it was a failure. I'm sure adult beverages if allowed/served would help the spirit. Great job to them but our car was mostly interested. It probably didn't help that they gave us a cookie just before they arrived so everyone was stuffing their face.   After that was story time, the lady reading the Story was animated and funny. Kudos to her.   She visited just before Santa.   Then Santa came. We were in one of the last cars so his visit was a bit rushed. He was nice and gave everyone a wooden train whistle.   ***********The entire operation is run by volunteers. So I'd like to thank all of them for their time!*******  This was he first time my son was not afraid of Santa:-)

reviews.author: John M.
reviews.description: This was a great little adventure from Cedar Park to Burnet Texas. Super We stayed in the Turquoise Room, which consisted of 2 tables, 8 chairs and two smaller windows. Staff was super friendly and knowledgeable...Once the train started the conductor came in to room to announce that there we several open seats in the main car...everyone got up and left leaving the wife and I in peace...Not that we are anti social, but it was peaceful to say the least...Good to catch up with each other, as we both work different hours...Truly not much to see on the way up...but it was a great ride....AC did work, not great but tolerable...I see in other reviews there were issues...You have freedom to roam Car to Car once the train gets rolling...and the train does turn around in Burnet...hard to explain, but it does...and we were able to see the other side of the tracks on the way home...Plenty to see and eat in Burnet...Our Car/cabin also came with free snacks and drinks...which is a great perk..as the snacks in the concession stand were quit expensive...The trip was worth it for us and will do it again next year with the granddaughter..

reviews.author: Liz I.
reviews.description: This review is based on my customer service experience with Zena, not the train ride itself (although I may come back and give an update!)  Zena is a lifesaver. Not literally, but she has made my train experience 2x as good. I bought a Groupon because I didn't even realize there was a train experience in Austin. After the headache of scheduling, our trip got canceled. Zena came in to save the day. She mailed me another gift certificate that expired in a year (vs the next week per my Groupon) AND she gifted us a little extra!  Sounds great, right? Unfortunately, the GC could not be redeemed online. After multiple tries of calling in (and getting a forever ring - no pick up), I was getting irritated.   I emailed Zena back asking for her advice. She wrote back in 24 hours and apologized for their phone service. She even offered to reserve me herself. After a few back-and-forth emails, she answered all my questions and got us all squared away.  Our train ride happens this weekend and I can only hope that the experience is similar to Zena's customer service.

reviews.author: Shradha A.
reviews.description: It's such an adorable idea - volunteers running a historic train line on weekends to give people an authentic experience. But the train is slow - really really slow. The view is simple and unmemorable. The FandB in the first class is simply a cinnamon roll and lemon cake with tea. They do have apples and oranges as well. The trip back was painful - we stood in the concession cart the entire time because the A/Cs didn't work and it was triple-digit hot on a September Saturday. Even my 5-year-old nephew, who is obsessed with trains and knows all there is to know about them, wasn't engaged in this ride much. Thankfully, we had carried board games and our own food so the ride to Burnet was okay but the ride back was really terrible.

reviews.author: James A.
reviews.description: I organized a group from Meetup.com to try this excursion and it was fun!  It's a laid-back trip to the Hill Country. My friends and I were in an Adults-Only car, the Rippling Stream, and we had a great time with each other and looking at the scenery.  I highly recommend this trip!

reviews.author: Katherine V.
reviews.description: The most horrible rip off of an experience I have ever had. I bought 4 tickets for the VIP lounge which included treats and drinks and a nicer car, it was none of those things. The food offered were store bought generic cookies and the drinks were either warm apple juice or water. The car lost the A.C. capacity on the return from the small town with nothing to offer and did not even have the gun fight reenactment due to the extreme heat, now imagine that extreme heat inside a metal sardine box. I invited my 72 year old father and I was genuinely worried we would have to rush him to the emergency room upon arrival. I chewed the place out for their false advertisement and putting the elderly and children at risk in the extreme heat without AC.   In summation, do not buy tickets to any of the events this was a horrible experience. I got my money almost a month later, and I will never return and I will warn anyone thinking about ever going to one of these fiascos.

reviews.author: Tim H.
reviews.description: As recent residents to the Austin area our 15 y/o son wanted to experience a classic train. We fortunately found the Austin Steam Train Association. We booked tickets on the Sunset Express trip. The Staff was all very friendly and knowledgeable.   You are able to bring your own drinks (non alcoholic) and snacks which is a plus. They do have a concessions car which is nice.   To us the trip was not as much about the scenery as it was the experience of a mode of travel long since gone.

reviews.author: Umeko V.
reviews.description: If you are going to the BlueBonnet festival, this is the way to go. Sit back, relax and enjoy the scenery, and when you get to the festival, no looking for parking.  Just jump off the train, and there you are.  Each train car has it's own characteristics, but take my word, spend the extra money for the air conditioned cars.  We had a chance to walk through the other cars, and even on a beautiful spring day, you can tell a big difference walking into the cars without A/C.  We rode on the City of Chicago, in a table for two, which had great views.  There was complimentary water, tea and snacks on our car.  The volunteer, Barbara, was informative about the train, wildflowers, and announced points of interest on the route.

reviews.author: Matthew H.
reviews.description: My family and I took a ride on the Hill Country Flyer and this a brief overview of our experience and I recommend you heed this review well.  ----------------------------  I visited and rode the September 7th 10:00 am to 5:00 pm ride to Burnett going out of Cedar Park Wirth the Austin Steam Train Association and I'd like to share my experience that day.   To begin the train left 20 minutes late from the terminal when it was communicated the train would be leaving promptly and on time consistently. Which is fine although it did negatively impact the quality of time spent in Burnett and exploring the town which was a key experience in the advertised outing. Another large disappointment was the lack of the advertised western gun fight. We saw no mention of it, nor display of it. Apparently that was another misrepresentation of the trip. It was advertised we would have two hours to explore downtown Burnett and have lunch. This was barely enough time to visit a local restaurant flooding with business from both local lunchtime and other passengers. With barely an hour in Burnett without enough time to eat we actually had to leave the restaurant we were at in a manic frenzy without eating, apologize to the staff at the restaurant for our rush due to this,and return to the train. Then upon returning at the specified time we still not even begin the process of departing until nearly 30 minutes past the time we were told to return! The. On the return trip we didn't even get above 10 mph on the speed making for a grueling and arduous journey back creating an atmosphere on complete misery on the entire train. On top of all of that the trains expected time to return was 5:00 we did not return until after 5:30! This is insane it officially help derail our entire vacation plan and helped out more of a strain on our time off. Meaning we had to rush and adjust our original plans.   Another issue with the experience was there little to no a/c in rear car named Rippling Stream on a day with temperatures rising above 95 degrees! Although the next car over had perfect a/c with a lower priced ticket. Paying for six tickets @55 dollars to sit in the heat in pool of our own sweat was not the idea of a luxury car provided by marketing materials. We actually had to use the pamphlets provided to make fans in order to be comfortable during the ride and continuously go into the other cars for refuge from the sweltering heat. Upon informing staff of the issue we were told once the train is moving we can go to other cars and stand in the cool air to gain some reprise from the heat.This is insane as we bought out the entire private room to have a bonding family experience we certainly were unable to enjoy. Also this car represented itself as a purchase of an adults only car ticket and children were running through the car. We wanted an experience that would supply with a relaxing adult atmosphere that was negatively impacted by this not being enforced.   Another major concern of mine is lack of communication from staff with the private areas of the train. Announcements regarding safety, departure time, arrival, landmarks etc were unheard in the private room and no effort was made by train personnel to inform us of anything. We were left alone with no information about anything given without having to seek out an attendant regularly. To mention with sound there was also an almost constant excessively loud screeching noise as we moved along at a slugs pace that I feel each passenger will hear in their nightmares of this ride for years to come.   This experience wound up being more stressful due to the previously mentioned circumstances causing our trip to be unenjoyable. Due to the dishonest representation of a truly climate controlled car, and times for departure misrepresented. Unfortunately this is not an outing that we would attended again or recommend to others visiting the Austin/Hill Country area. This is not something we would recommend for anyone trying to relax or enjoy a vacation.

reviews.author: Jennifer W.
reviews.description: Such a cute place! Loved the outdoor and indoor areas. Brewery is right next door and you can order from either and pay at one. Wine was good too!

reviews.author: Ara A.
reviews.description: They have a winery and a brewery which is great when you have a group with people who like different taste. Lots of games and seating areas. You can have a flight or the tasting menu, lots options.

reviews.author: Megan L.
reviews.description: My friends and I had such a fun time this past Saturday! Wine and beer is well priced, and the space is great to spend a summer day with your friends. I really liked the rosé wine, and my friends and I ordered truffle fries from the food truck. The only thing I would change about our experience is that I wish we had made a reservation 24 hours in advance because you can't order charcuterie boards and wine flights without one.   Everyone is really nice, and on a chilly day, they even have blankets. I highly recommend making the trek out here!

reviews.author: Jaclyn L.
reviews.description: It's beautiful! The rose is perfect for a summer day, there was live music, food truck, axe throwing and an amazing outdoor landscape!   A wonderful summer day spent here!

reviews.author: Jamie P.
reviews.description: We had a great time relaxing in the beautiful sunshine at Bell Springs! There is a winery and a brewery on site so everyone likely has an option they'll like = Best of both worlds. They have plenty of outdoor seating, which you could choose to sit in the sun or under the trees in the shade. We split a glass of rose and their sweet white and I would recommend either one. The sommelier was super sweet and helped us choose our wines. Would definitely recommend a stop here to relax and enjoy nature with a glass of wine in hand!

reviews.author: Anthony L.
reviews.description: This is a fun place to hang out with friends!   The wine is pretty good. We shared a bottle of Rosé. The real appeal of this place is the setting itself. There is ample outdoor seating under big shade trees! It's a pretty place.  There is also a brewery on site, but I cannot speak to the quality of the beer. We stuck with wine on this trip. I would definitely come back and try other wines and the beers offered!

reviews.author: Luke P.
reviews.description: Completely unacceptable management. For about 2 hours a group of individuals where shouting at two tables, yelling sexually explicit language, swearing profusely, and were clearly unable to drive. At a place that prides itself in a family atmosphere, where kids are running around playing in the grass and trees, this is completely unacceptable. I am looking forward to management/ownership response to this review. In a region where wineries, breweries and distilleries are a dime a dozen, plenty of opportunities to take my business elsewhere when we come visit.  What should really concern the owners and management about what happened at Bell Springs is the fact that:  1) The Hays County sheriff was called after the incident because it was so egregious. Enough of these reviews and they will be lining up outside the parking lot for DWIs.  2) The staff (7:00 pm on 6/19) did absolutely nothing to cut off a clearly over-intoxicated group that was negatively impacting people around them  3) The staff's response (blonde and burnette hostesses), ver batim, to the vulgar language and rowdiness was "free speech" and "you are the problem - I know those people".  Fantastic - best of luck in your future endeavors . Your stellar response caused one of our group to cancel their wine membership.

reviews.author: Shanita F.
reviews.description: They have three long tables for guests to sit and enjoy the tasting. It snowed the weekend we went, so of course we were inside. However, they do have an outdoor patio, bar and high bar seating. The outdoor seating probably really nice in good weather.   Call ahead or make reservations online. It's very easy and they do allow you to amend reservations over the phone.   They produce really great wine and there's a great selection to choose from. The staff is very knowledgeable about their wines and answered all of our questions. Testing comes with a **small** array of cheeses, nuts and crackers.

reviews.author: Jenny S.
reviews.description: This is a beautiful winery. Plenty of tables spread around the grounds under trees. Lots of room for kids to run around out there. We sat up on the patio with our dog and enjoyed a lovely wine tasting. We chose the solo tour which was $15 for 5 generous pours of delicious wine. All the staff we interacted with were very friendly and helpful. The one low point is the food truck. We got the currywurst for $10 which was good, but not a large enough serving for the price. The more upsetting part was the pretzel we got (also $10, which is very expensive). The prestel was small, hard (even though it was supposed to be a soft pretzel), and flavorless. The mustard cheese dip did its best to save it, but it wasn't enough.

reviews.author: Alexa S.
reviews.description: Cute spot and their brewery next door is awesome too! Bell Springs is in a nice location and it is so green! The wine is yummy, tastings are nice sized pours! Only reason I am giving 4 stars is because when you make a reso for wine tasting and charcuterie, don't expect a lot of cheese and meats HA! It was so small, we were cracking up. I would recommend bringing your own snacks and food! Otherwise, awesome spot and I can't wait to go back!

reviews.author: Xiaoting X.
reviews.description: Beautiful winery and relaxing porch. However most wines are sourced from Lubbock and not from Austin.  montepulciano is from the region and pretty bold.

reviews.author: Jalise F.
reviews.description: I really enjoyed my visit here. I'm not much of a wine drinker but they were able to answer any questions I had about the wine. Also it was snowing when I went and that made the experience all the better. Will most definitely return on my next trip to Texas!

reviews.author: Anna O.
reviews.description: Nothing  but amazing things to say! We recently hosted our Dripping Springs 10 Year High school reunion at Bell Springs Winery and it was a great experience. Nate and Laura were wonderful to work with and they took care of everything making it super easy for me. The location is perfect and off the main road and the layout of the outdoor and indoor areas are well suited for any size group. Defiantly consider Bell Springs for your next event!

reviews.author: Manuela A.
reviews.description: What a little surprise! I liked their porch and plenty of outdoor seating. They have a great brewery on location so there is something for everyone. They did generous pours of 3 wine tastings for $20. We got a bottle of Cab with grapes from Washington state. No surprise as Texas cab grapes do no yield good wine. We enjoyed our time here!

reviews.author: Anna M.
reviews.description: I have been here numerous times and always had an awesome experience but today was the most unacceptable experience I have ever had ANYWHERE. I was here with my family, parents, and my brothers family with a total of 5 kids (not unusual to see kids here). While here, we became aware of a group that was likely overserved and using foul/vulgar language that we tried to ignore for a long time. Once we heard the phrase "fat c*ck" at a ridiculous volume my husband asked them to please keep it down, which resulted in a huge altercation with various threats/insults from their end. Despite their behavior management still allowed them to stay. What's worth noting is multiple people had already complained about this group and others joined my husband in attempting them to quiet down- so they were affecting loads of people at the winery. Eventually things calmed down and the argument broke, but as we were leaving they said loudly for us to hear "I'm so glad that douchebag is leaving" so I gave them the finger as I was walking away (I will concede this was adding fuel to the fire but I was so fed up at this point) and they screamed to me "FUCK YOU MOM" across the grass. Managements response? Free speech allows them to say whatever they want. Apparently this nice hill country spot is going for the dirty 6th vibe. Save your money and go somewhere with enough pride to expel those who can't keep it together while I use my own right to free speech to notify everyone this place doesn't care about their patrons.

reviews.author: Michael P.
reviews.description: Understaffed.  Cannot manage overserved men and women who are creating bad examples for family customers there as members to enjoy the facilities.  Staff is useless.  Take my membership; we are out.  There are many Other places to enjoy.

reviews.author: Paula P.
reviews.description: I am a resident of Dripping Springs and have been a frequent patron of Bell Springs Winery. I found this family-friendly venue to be welcoming and beautiful. It was for this reason that I suggested that my kids, with their families, join my husband and me for a Father's Day celebration on Saturday evening, June 19th. When we arrived just before 5 pm, we found a good picnic spot in the shade near the bag game. We all noticed, or rather heard, a very boisterous group of 12 to 15 people sitting near the brewery. As the evening progressed, and I am assuming more alcohol was consumed, the group became louder and more profane. We attempted to ignore them, but soon it was impossible due to the volume and the increasingly prevalent and disgusting language. At that point, and because we had 5 young children with us, my son-in-law went over to the group and respectfully asked them to turn down the volume so that my Grandchildren would no longer be exposed to words like "F*ck and C*ck". He was immediately met with a barrage of personal slurs and threats. 2 staff members (2 young ladies, one light-haired and the other dark-haired) working that evening came over to the group, however, incredibly, the inebriated party was allowed to remain on the premises. Shortly after, every family packed up and went home, including our group.  When walking to the parking lot to leave, a particularly vile young woman yelled obscenities at my son-in-law and daughter. I turned around and went over to the group. When I arrived, I was also barraged with a variety of slurs and called a "C*nt". Once again, the 2 female staff members came over to the table to intercede. At this point, the dark-haired staff member shared with me that she "knew the group" of offenders, which helped me understand why these folks had not been asked to leave. If you happen to know staff, you can act like filthy pigs, with the knowledge that your actions will have no repercussion, regardless of the profoundly negative impact on everyone else looking to enjoy wine and food with their families.  To add insult to injury, staff had the unmitigated gall to suggest that I was the problem, not the drunk and vulgar group. When I questioned staff (dark haired young lady) why they permitted such obnoxious behavior from any patron, she suggested that hurling profanity toward others was protected under free speech. Staff continually suggested that our "conversation was over", indicating that they wanted me to leave. Clearly, the privilege of free speech isn't applied equally to all patrons visiting Bell Springs.  In the past 15 months, I have recommended Bell Springs to dozens of family and friends. Now, I plan to exercise my right of free speech in every forum available to tell acquaintances and strangers alike about my experience, advising that Bell Springs is not worthy of anyone's patronage.

reviews.author: Robert R.
reviews.description: The wine was good.  The lawn for tasting was ample.  The amount of things to do was tremendous.  I highly recommend this, but the wine is a little over priced for its taste and quality.

reviews.author: Genette G.
reviews.description: One star is too much for this place. I have seen several people treated badly. Everyone who works there look down on people. I have witnessed people harrased and the winery does nothing about it.

reviews.author: Amanda B.
reviews.description: Owner is very rude and unprofessional. He was very short with me and disrespectful. I feek bad for the staff as they are not trained well and over worked.

reviews.author: Gary G.
reviews.description: Classy space, nice location and excellent wine.  Had the distinct pleasure of being served by waitress Jennie Tedesco while drinking an excellent red wine blend.  Jennie's ability to know exactly what we wanted before we did was truly enjoyable and her knowledge of wine and friendly professionalism made for a great Saturday outing.  Have been to both the Grape Creek Vineyards near Fredericksburg and to the Georgetown tasting room.  Each are excellent, but the Georgetown location with its wonderful staff are the reason we keep our coming back.

reviews.author: Natalia R.
reviews.description: Covid review 12/2020 No seating for non-members and I suppose no kindness for them either. I went to the front and was rudely "greeted". We left because why would I purchase wine from someone who seems to treat me without professionalism since I'm not a member? Hmm not a way to acquire new members!

reviews.author: Sarah S.
reviews.description: This was an amazing experience. The food was just as good as the wine !! The pizzas were amazing. The charcuterie board was to die for, meatballs were okay, and garlic hummus was a winner.

reviews.author: William B.
reviews.description: Conveniently located on the Georgetown Square, Grape Creek Vineyards tasting room is a welcoming oasis of great wines and friendly "tasting ambassadors". You know Grape Creek's wine is good: they earned almost 2 dozen medals, including three Double Golds, this year at the prestigious San Francisco Wine Competition. And their wins encompass all styles, with Double Gold wins for red, white and Port. My Tasting Ambassador, Sandy, was exceptional! As we talked, she discerned my tastes and made a couple of recommendations that turned out to be spot on. She was knowledgeable and responsive, and a delight to talk with. Having been to many tasting rooms and wineries in the Texas Hill Country as well as from the California wine regions to the New York Finger Lakes, my experience at Grape Creek exceeded my expectations. Highly recommended!

reviews.author: Phillip H.
reviews.description: These guys are extremely rude. We all purchased memberships and wanted to enjoy our wine on the patio which was mostly empty. Since they made us split up our party of six we got two tables that were close together. Apparently management had a problem with my girlfriend and I orienting our chairs towards our friends table so we could all talk to each other and came and got in our faces to tell us we have to turn our chairs around and face forward. What is this kindergarten? The wine was alright, but definitely not good enough to justify the $40 per bottle price tag. I've found better bottles at HEB for under $20. Don't waste your time or money. There are plenty of other wineries in the area of the same quality that are more affordable and less rude

reviews.author: Erica G.
reviews.description: Grape Creek is my official go to for Georgetown vino. After signing up in Fredericksburg, I've quickly come to LOVE their red wines...particularly Bellisimo. It is absolutely delish and my go to red for my collection and for gifting to friends.   While the main building itself is somewhat small and doesnt offer the option to sit downstairs (GC....this is overdue), there is a members only room available upstaird with views of the Gtown Square.  The patio however is the reason people gravitate towards this winery. There is live music, nice fans to keep you cool in summer and heaters for the winter.  My only dislike is the changes hours...it closes at 6:30. Far too early and down the street are alternatives that stay open til 9 or later.

reviews.author: Angela P.
reviews.description: This was the second stop during my Saturday night wine bender. I've never been here before. My friend is a wine club member and invited us to accompany her and her significant other to a tasting. We ended up enjoying a bottle! It was delicious. We sat in the reserved section on the second floor and finished the bottle and relaxed. Grape Creek has a nice selection of local wines to choose. Although the facility is small, the atmosphere is friendly and quaint.

reviews.author: Shelley F.
reviews.description: Visited during a recent trip and was delighted.  EVE WAS AMAZING - she explained things so well on our tasting!

reviews.author: Russ V.
reviews.description: Good wine, fun old/down town feels, great staff, what more do you want? We signed up for the membership cuz yum!

reviews.author: J. S.
reviews.description: Could not love this winery more. Although... standing in line when you first walk-in did seem a bit off, it was merely just a way to help usher traffic through more efficiently. Luckily, the line went quickly or this would probably be a different type of review, as someone * wink wink* who doesn't do well with lines for absolutely anything, except that one Prince concert 30 years ago.   Needless to say, we came, we tasted, we joined the wine club and now we are big fans. Especially of their Rose of Malbec. That deliciously tasting watermelon jolly rancher (without the sugar) wine has changed wine drinking for me and completely justifies the $30 price tag.

reviews.author: Kami S.
reviews.description: We were sharing a couple bottles on the patio (my friend is a member) when an employee (who was drinking a glass of wine herself) came out and told us extremely rudely that they were closed and we needed to get out. She started jerking things away from the table while we were still sitting there. We had previously been sitting there calmly, not being loud or offensive in any way - it felt very abrupt and extremely rude. We realized after we were booted out that closing was at 5 and this intrusion happened at 5:10, it wasn't like they were waiting on us for an hour. Even though my friend is a member we won't be coming back.

reviews.author: Joey G.
reviews.description: We bought our membership in Fredericksburg, but we live in Round Rock. When you join the club, you get two glasses a day, and we are regulars at the Georgetown square. Everyone there is very friendly. We do miss the live music in the back. But it's nice to grab our glasses and sit on the square.

reviews.author: Mike M.
reviews.description: Fantastic service and wonderful atmosphere. This place does it right. It is very comfortable, the staff is welcoming and just an overall great place to spend some time and relax on the square in Georgetown. Whether in the members only room upstairs or out on the private patio, this is a very nice place.

reviews.author: Emily M.
reviews.description: I'm really unsure what to say about this place. I've only been here a couple of times and the staff member that helped us was amazing. I decided to join the wine club because of her level of service. However, it's hard to get a hold of someone on the phone. I have a simple question to ask but no one will ever pick up the phone. When select the button to speak to the tasting room, their automated service starts all over again. Yes, I can email, but for a simple question, picking up the phone should be an easy option as well.  Also, the times on yelp versus their times on the phone are inconsistent. That needs to be updated.  Bottomline, they lack communication.  It's really annoying and frustrating. I plan on canceling my wine club membership and going elsewhere due to the experience that I've had.

reviews.author: Kenneth B.
reviews.description: This winery is smack downtown Georgetown and has a really great feel. It has a great assortment of wine that is reasonably priced. I really like this winery, with the exclusive access to seating upstairs. I love the live entertainment outside lounge area. I really like this winery! I also like how EVERY time you come to the winery, you get a complimentary glass of wine! Of course, you need a membership.  I don't live in the area so I have a trek to make to receive my complimentary glass of wine for me and a guest. However, when I am in the area you better believe I am here. I just started my membership last visit but failed to write a review after a couple of bottles. My apologies. I was informed that my three bottles qill be mailed to my residence in Harker Heights, Texas. I will be sure to post how that goes. You can cancel the membership at anytime. More to follow after I really get a chance to experience this establishment.

reviews.author: Pamela M.
reviews.description: Grape Creek Vineyards is about 2 miles from my best friend's house in downtown Georgetown. We had so much fun there!  My sorority sisters came to Georgetown for Austin's ACL Fest and added on extra days to sightsee.   Grape Creek was a wonderful respite.  You stand in line, describe your likes to the salesperson, and taste. Then, you get wine by the glass (I think it was 10$/glass) to enjoy on their relaxing patio, and bottles to go.   My BF is a frequent member and has a card to get 2 free glasses of wine a month.   A very nice spot to relax and enjoy good wine and good conversation.   Thank you Grape Creek Vineyards!

reviews.author: Adam H.
reviews.description: After joining the wine club on our visit to the Main Street location in Fredericksburg, we picked up our June 2018 shipment in Georgetown and had a fun day on the square. It's going to be a quarterly experience for my wife and I, which includes a 6-sample tasting or half glass each visit and access to the upstairs member only area. We went on a Saturday around 5:00 and it was busy! The wait for the tasting was only a few minutes since they fully staffed the counter. I think I saw them doing 5 couples or groups at a time.  She told us that we can order delivery from Gumbo's around the corner or bring in any food that we want! The offer live music on the weekends on the patio and dogs are welcome out there. The member only area was packed with people, so it was a bit hot, but had comfortable couches and chairs, many windows overlooking the courthouse and town square, and some salespeople offering tastes of the Owner's Club wines. I only took off a star because the member's area was hot and could use some more seating and a server would be great since it takes a while to get another glass or make a purchase by standing in line more than once.  The had quite a bit of wine related merchandise, cheese, olive oils and vinegars, and cookbooks downstairs.

reviews.author: Zane G.
reviews.description: Elizabeth, Julie, Kelly, Jenn and crew always take care of us when we come in.  We love being able to come in after work and get a glass of wine. Being part of the members club is certainly worth it.   My favorite wine is the Cab Blanc.

reviews.author: Nina H.
reviews.description: Stopped by here because I am a member and had never been to this location and was in the neighborhood.  It is a nice storefront on the square in Georgetown, which is a terribly cute area if you haven't been.  Got my free member glass and took it out on the back patio to enjoy.  Plenty of tables and shade there and some light classic rock, which made for a nice relaxing atmosphere.  Also I went upstairs to check out the members only lounge.  There was nothing free being handed out there food or sipping wise, but it was a comfortable place with lots of leather chairs, and if the winery was crowded, I could see escaping up here.  The wine itself is very good, something for every palate, even the dry red drinkers like myself.  If you are into wine at all, stop by and do a tasting, and I think you will be happy you did.  I plan to come back anytime I'm in the Georgetown area again.

reviews.author: Josh O.
reviews.description: Been members for a while now.  Finally got a chance to come to the Georgetown location on a Sunday around 4pm.   Place was a mess. People everywhere with no special lines for members Or any direction other than a sign that said everyone get in line.  Not sure the value of paying to be a member for this space.  Also a 21 and over rule in the tasting room. Most serious wine folks have kids.  Seriously reconsidering our membership and if it's with it. My suggestion would be to expand as quick as possible if you're that popular. Otherwise, do away with memberships benefits and just open to the public.  4 stars because the wine is amazing.

reviews.author: Matt M.
reviews.description: This brewery is a 10/10 if Yelp let give this opinion I would. The bartender was absolutely amazing giving me amazing recommendations. The GM proceeded to stay late with us and show us the absolute best of the best mead I have ever had. He was amazing the bartender was amazing and if I ever re-vist Austin this is a must have on the to do list. Do NOT miss out on this amazing experience. Do not go to Austin beer works this place is literally 10x better if not more.

reviews.author: Jake H.
reviews.description: I really like the beer here. I love the $18 flight and the pint glass you get to take home at the end is the coolest pint glass I've ever owned. Unfortunately, they do not allow dogs inside. As a dog owner who lives in the brewery district, this establishment is simply off my list anytime I go out with my little gal.   I do love this place but it's hard to give a perfect score to a place I can't frequent. Especially when they have ~10 competitors in a 5 minute radius and none of them share the same policy. As a result, I am updating my review from 5 to 4 stars.

reviews.author: Cynthia L.
reviews.description: I sampled a flight of their Belgian style beers and enjoyed them all. The staff was polite, and the food from the Emoji food truck was tasty and reasonably priced.

reviews.author: Roland D.
reviews.description: Cool Staff, great beer, really good vibes all around.

reviews.author: Jana N.
reviews.description: This place is on my Covid-19 safe list. They will continue to require masks.

reviews.author: Dan P.
reviews.description: Overall vibe: relaxed, quirky Austin  Service: good beer knowledge. Hillary was very nice at the counter.  Beer: excellent quality. Great Friday from raspberry wheat beer to Belgian style ale  Overall cleanliness: above average  Price: average for good craft beer

reviews.author: Chris T.
reviews.description: This is a nice stop. The entryway can get a slight bottleneck, just be patient. The beer is worth the wait. I got the seasonal raspberry beer that was brewed for owner daughter wedding, oh my gosh! Delicious and refreshing. I ended up buying a 6 pack to take home. I think it is gone now, but so good!

reviews.author: Taylor Z.
reviews.description: Large spacious venue with plenty of outdoor seating as well. I love that have arcade games and foosball, fun spot for a group. Come thristy.

reviews.author: Alex C.
reviews.description: I'm a fan of dark Belgian style beer that's not too sweet so Adalbert's gets five stars right away.  I love the Philosophizer and the October Rust.  There seems to be good social distancing. There's hand sanitizer on the counter. Growlers are a possibility as are CDB sodas. The people are friendly and seem to know about the beer. I only discovered this place after the pandemic it started so I've never really spent time inside. But I've been sitting on my own porch enjoying it quite a bit and when things get back to normal I hope to spend a few hours at Adelbert's.

reviews.author: Saunya O.
reviews.description: This was a great brewery to go to after work for drinks with friends or coworkers. I love the idea that's you are actually in the brewery itself.   The neat thing is that they have artwork that's for sale on the walls. The art adds character and is a large variety of different themes all from local artists.   No good is served inside the brewery but there is a really good food truck on the outside.   The beers are amazing and you can sample before you buy.  Liked this brewery and beers are very creative.

reviews.author: Missy J.
reviews.description: Love coming here and just hanging out. The bartenders are always very sweet and willing to let you try things before you get a whole glass. I always enjoy their IPAs. They have a food truck outside with I think chicken I usually just get the fresh popped popcorn it's delicious and great to snack on while drinking beer. They have a Nintendo Wii with Mario kart and two old-school arcade games they also have a Foos ball table and darts. There's also boardgames that you can check out with giving them your ID, an awesome place to hang out with friends, kids and dogs!

reviews.author: Jodi H.
reviews.description: I had my first Adelbert's beer through HEB, with their Naked Nun witbier. I have been hooked since then and finally made it into their tasting room.   It. Was. Heaven. They have an outdoors area that's shaded for those with doggos or who want to enjoy the heat and eat from their food truck. I had the Triple B, which was surprisingly crisp and floral for a belgian. They had a variety of beers which I wanted to taste, but we arrived late with one hour to spare before closing. That just means I need to pay another visit to truly enjoy the place.  They have a private parking area shared with neighboring businesses and strong wifi. The best part is the indoors games like 4-player Mario Kart (WHAT!), darts, and a bunch of board games. They also give free stickers, plus our lady taptender that day was so kind and welcoming.

reviews.author: Tisha T.
reviews.description: Met up with some work peeps for a happy hour of sorts. I originally didn't plan to attend since it's a brewery and I hate beer with a passion. However I checked out their site, saw they had some wine options and a food truck--so I happily tagged along. The bartender who greeted us gave us the rundown of everything. Served us with a smile and was very informative about the beers, of course. I had a great bottle of pinot grigio while my friends enjoyed the various beers available. I had a great time checking out the art that they have on the walls for sale. We also played a game of jumbo sized connect four and Mario Kart on the big screen. A large collection of board games are also available to borrow while hanging out enjoying your drink in the taproom. Very cool place, warm vibes. Great food truck on site as well.  Definitely will return soon and bring my beer drinking friends.

reviews.author: Justin N.
reviews.description: Really good beer at Adebert's. Lots of cool wood barrels and lots of people around for a fun Friday Night. At certain times you can challenge the bartender to a game of Mario Kart which is truly unique but just add the the overall great experience at Adelbert's

reviews.author: Alysha M.
reviews.description: This place is great! Get the wristband if you're a first timer- only $15 for six "half pours" which are definitely more like 3/4 pours haha  The mango wit, naked nun, and hibiscus saison are AMAZINGGG.   Cool art, live music, food truck (although they left early, which sucked).  The only real disappointment? The brewery closes at 10- we coulda stayed all night!

reviews.author: Christian C.
reviews.description: Awesome beer, and a very chill location to hang out with friends and family.  Children are allowed as well, which is very convenient for fellow parents!  They've got a bunch of cool artwork from local artists, giant Jenga, a foosball table, and live music to keep you entertained.  They also have great food truck options during Taproom hours.    $14 for 6 half pours and a free pint glass is a pretty amazing deal, especially due to the quality and content of the beer.  If you're into light, crisper beers, try the Naked Nun or the Philosophizer.  If you like the darker stuff, the Black Rhino is your friend.  They also have some great sours!

reviews.author: Dawn H.
reviews.description: Three words: Belgium style brews! Oh my goodness, where have you been hiding from me Adelbert's?! This is by far one of my most favorite craft breweries in all of Austin, if not in the United States. For those of you that really know me, you know that I L.O.V.E. Belgian beers...so much so that, yes, I traveled to Belgium JUST for the beers (okay, I ate some mussels and saw some pretty cool stuff too, but...). For those of you not in the know (no insult meant for those who are), Belgian style beers are pretty high in ABV, so amateurs enter gently. Just looking out for my Yeeps! :D  Adelbert's doesn't look like much at all from the outside. Tucked away in a warehouse district, it can a tad difficult to find, particularly at night - just look for the little white lights and the picnic tables outside. Park, walk through the plastic flat "doors" and you will discover a beautiful huge space with stacks and stacks of barrels, merchandise for sale, lots of local art hanging on the walls to purchase adds to the ambiance; plus games to play such as giant Jenga, foosball, and darts and that's one fine outing.   But the beer! Oh my gosh - the beer. Handcrafted at its best. So amazingly fantastic and such a great deal. On your first visit be certain to buy the 6 half pour (really close to full pours - yay) tastings for $13. You get to keep the glass and get $2 off beers when you bring it back on your next visit. Regular prices range from $4-6 a glass, which is phenominal in the first place for such high quality ale.   ALL great, two personal standouts for me were: *Flyin' Monks Quadrupel: 10.9%ABV, aged in rum barrels with hints of spice, deep, dark, and lovely. *Philosophizer Saison: An easy choice. 7.8% ABV, very mild carbonation with a hint of pepper. Fantastic.     To add some icing to this already oh so sweet find, the founder and brewmaster Scott and staff cannot be any more friendly or knowledgeable about the beers and brewery.   Highly highly highly recommend. Simply doesn't get better than this IMHO. Cheers!  TIPS:  *The brewery has a license so you can take a large bottle home for a reasonable price of about $9 to $12, which is average. They also sell retail at area Austin locations (visit their website for exact locations).  *Tours are available (see website for details).   *They typically have a food truck on site on Saturdays.  *Fido friendly pergola area - not allowed inside.

reviews.author: Sam V.
reviews.description: Ya'll are probably already aware of my latest and greatest obsession with collecting pint glasses from assorted breweries. For our first stop in Austin, we stopped by this unassuming warehouse. As we walked in, the live jazz band was jammin' and the beer taps were flowin'.   Michael and his bearded friend were fantastic bartenders. I really appreciated their hospitality. Michael instantly could tell I was new to this particular brewery and proceeded to explain the process to tasting their beer samples. He even noted that I had a minor with me and offered a brewed hibiscus tea for him. They really cater to all ages! We paid $13 for six half poured samples from a souvenir Belgian tasting glass. One yellow wristband later, my siblings and I were playing ping-pong and giant Jenga in the back of the warehouse.  The stringed lights on the ceiling made it feel welcome and homey. They had a wall of local art for sale ranging from $30-$300! I had my eye on a Sinatra painting, and as luck would have it, it was indeed the $300 piece lol. I stared at it longingly for most of the night, but couldn't bring myself to throw down on it. My favorite craft brews of the night were the Naked Nun and the Philosophizer. Brilliant names and great hoppy flavors.  Once it got too muggy in the taproom, we ventured out to get some grub. The food truck of the night was Emoji Grilled Cheese. (See their yelp site for my review) It was mouthwatering and delicious. We visited a couple other breweries throughout our trip, but Adelbert's was my all-time favorite.   Thanks for a great time!   -xoxoxo

reviews.author: Paul K.
reviews.description: Solid, well made beers ranging from wits to saisons to sours to pale ales and IPAs.  Nice range of beers, all done with style.

reviews.author: Geoffrey C.
reviews.description: From the outside, this place looks quite small but it's a lot larger than I thought. Seating inside and outside. Also, what kind of brewery would this be if they did not have board games to play as you drink?  The Mango Wit is good and refreshing. Mango flavor is not as present as I like, but the hint of it is good enough.

reviews.author: Roger G.
reviews.description: Awesome small winery.  Wine is good and the owners are very hospitable.  Highly recommend you pay them a visit!

reviews.author: Amberly F.
reviews.description: We have loved this place for over a year now ! We as wine club members enjoy our complimentary glass of wine on a date night and come out for al the fun events like the annual chili cook off and Christmas stroll.  The view is breathtaking as well as the company. This place provides a perfect get away from the big city and a great family feeling. We will continue to come back and recommend it to anyone who lives a good spot to relax and have a glass of wine.  Also, kid friendly when certain events happen and animal friendly as there is a winery dog who hangs out and lives in the guest.

reviews.author: Lori T.
reviews.description: Love, love, LOVE KFire!!!! Being a cab person, I highly recommend Engine 16. The cream cheese snack plate is excellent, too. They even have gluten free crackers.   The grounds are rustic but thoroughly enjoyable. The owners are knowledgeable.  And the dog!!!!   Go. Just go. Let loose for a change.

reviews.author: Matt L.
reviews.description: Gail and Kenny (the owners) are down to earth and run a unpretentious winery. I enjoy sweet wines and their "Cadet" wine was my favorite.  On a sunny day it would be a great peaceful place to spend the afternoon. It has plenty good wine, outdoor games and seating.  well worth the drive.  On a separate note I went on a rainy day and we walked inside to find Kenny and Gail's visiting family inside. They were some of the nicest people I've ever met.  Thanks for the fun afternoon

reviews.author: Mindy H.
reviews.description: The owners, Kenny and Gail are an amazing couple. Kfire is the result of many hours of their passion and love and years of planning. They are not new to the Texas wine industry.  They previously owned Lakeview Winery and Tasting room. Their dream though was to have their own space, production site, and vineyard.  Which led them to break ground and open Kfire.  They have a small tasting room, production pad, and have planted several rows with different varietals.  The local wine aficionados are most excited about the Tannat that they planted.  They also have a beautiful outdoor stone campfire circle, made out of the limestone they displaced when planting their rows of grape vines.  The tasting room is small and quaint. Kenny is a retired fireman, and you will find touches of former fire fighting equipment and artifacts throughout the tasting room.  There is also a nice selection of cigars for purchase.  You can do a tasting of five wines of your choice from their vast selection.  They have three whites, a couple reds, and a variety of fruit wines to select from.  I think the tasting was $10-15.  If you buy two bottles of wine, they will waive the tasting fee.  The bottle prices are reasonable.    Currently their wines are made from grapes sourced from Texas and other states.  They utilize some varietals in their blends that are not common to find.  It was great to experience something different. All of their wines were OK, except their Viognier was my least favorite.  The wines are approachable and ready to drink now. The whites are on the drier side, and have a nice bright acidity profile to it, which makes it pair well with food.  My favorite of the red was the Spotted Dog, a blend of Cab/Merlot/Montepulciano.  Out of the fruit wines, I enjoy the refreshing and bright Rhubarb wine called the Cadet.  It tastes like a great rhubarb strawberry pie, that is tart and light on sugar, and not too sweet.  The also have two other fruit ones to select from, the Tropical Isle, and Texas Brigade (Blackcherry).  They also have a small selection of three different food items to select from.    I am excited to see what the future holds for Kenny and Gail.

reviews.author: Lisa H.
reviews.description: Just happened to visit here because we didn't want a long drive for a winery visit in a beautiful day. Gail and Kenny welcomed us as we began our tasting. The wines are light and lovely and the experience definitely one we will repeat.  We joined the wine club and had a glass sitting out on the wonderful patio overlooking the vineyard.  Definitely worth a trip!!

reviews.author: Reynaldo B.
reviews.description: This is one of my favorite wineries! The owners Kenny and Gail are amazing people. I literally drive from San Antonio up there and drink wine, enjoy the day, and see Rescue (their vineyard dog). Haven't had a wine I don't like and their events they have periodically are great too. Definitely worth a drive to visit and check them out.

reviews.author: David W.
reviews.description: Giving this winery 3.5 stars. Pros: Friendly knowledgable staff, good wines (i tried Cab blend and Sangiovese-both quite good. The Sunday we were there, they had a sax player who was very good. They also had a food truck with so.e delicious Cuban food.  I was not impressed with the washer and horseshoe pits. My recommendation would be to hire a landscaping firm to upgrade these areas.  There is not much else to look at so some landscaping seating and shade would go a long way. Also, the food truck service was very slow.  My last comment is that the bottle prices seem high so I didn't buy any wine.  I hesitate to mention this however as the wine was good and I have no understanding of what the owner's cost is to produce.

reviews.author: Kara S.
reviews.description: Kfire winery and vineyard is my top winery that i been too. The customer service can't be beat and no matter what type of wine you like you will find something in either whites, reds or the sweets. I cant say 1 bad thing about kfire! Im pretty picky with wine and when we went here i fell in love and we became members that day.

reviews.author: Richard M.
reviews.description: A quaint winery started by an amazing couple, Kenny and Gail Fowler, located just north of Liberty Hill in Bertram off 183N and County Road 212. Kenny is a retired firefighter and thus the inspiration for the name of the winery.  A great wine tasting and overview of the facility was awesome.  Looking forward to the "Winetastic Affair" (a wine/food pairing) on Sept 22 between 3-7.  As Ken states, if you know any firefighters, have them bring us their department patch and receive a free glass of wine.!!

reviews.author: Amrita J.
reviews.description: Great stop on your trip to Dripping Springs. A family owned and run business. The owners are super friendly, and it's such a relaxing atmosphere. I had the blackberry smash with vodka and it was so good. They have the option of vodka or gin in your cocktail depending on your preference.   Definitely a great way to spend a day!

reviews.author: Dave M.
reviews.description: We spent the weekend visiting distilleries and this was very disappointing.   It's not busy at all but they still gave us gin instead of vodka.  It would be okay to play some music as it's awkwardly quiet due to the lack of patrons.  Finally, the people at the counter seemed annoyed with people overall.  Another couple in  the parking lot stopped us and asked if we had the same bad experience so it was not just us.

reviews.author: Amy S.
reviews.description: Had a great stop here. The blackberry smash was amazing. The Helen's were amazing too. They are very eco friendly, affordable and yummy. And the people were friendly. Win win win trifecta! We left with four bottles.

reviews.author: Jeff P.
reviews.description: Family owned and operated distillery makes for a welcoming experience.  Not like other local "corporate" locations.   Patio is large with plenty of comfortable chairs.   Vodka and Gin are amazing.   My wife enjoyed the Gin sample which was truly surprising.   She a vodka gal.   This is a must stop.  Bypass the corporate spots and come here first.

reviews.author: Christian W.
reviews.description: Definitely a hidden place with a great view! Glad we stopped at this place after seeing a sign off the side of the road and following a winding path down to see this gem.  Very homey vibes with a great patio for outdoor seeing that just has a fantastic view of the hill country. Decently priced drinks consisting of either gin or vodka.  Seating is pretty limited inside, but the outdoor space is just amazing and honestly makes the experience really that much better. I'd highly recommend 'The Bullfrog' with vodka. Tasty drink, but not overpowering and has a nice kick (smooth vodka that doesn't burn like gasoline).  P.S. They have some cool looking merch! Make sure to take a look at their terrariums...they are wicked!

reviews.author: Mindy H.
reviews.description: Frog Pond Distillery was a pleasant surprise.  I have been wanting to come here for a while now, but always drive-by, and don't get a chance to turn around.  However, this time I made a trip purposefully to stop in.  I am glad I did.  Frog Pond is a family-owned business and passion project. The entire family was behind the bar the day my friend and I stopped in except for mom and I think a daughter.  The family owns the land and has slowly overtime built the tasting room and production area themselves.  They currently make a vodka and gin.  They offered us a free sip of each to determine which we would prefer in one of their handcrafted cocktails.  Both had a nice flavor profile that blends well in cocktails.  Their cocktails were creative and they mentioned the family came up with the recipes together.  The cocktails were delicious and very reasonably priced.  Their space has a fun modern 50's theme.  They have an outdoor patio you can sit back and relax on a nice day.

reviews.author: Rachel A.
reviews.description: This is a family run business, which is a major plus!   Love supporting local, small family operated businesses. Their vodka is top notch and their featured cocktails are great.  The views from the porch are amazing and so serene. Definitely coming back for another round.

reviews.author: Anastacia R.
reviews.description: My friends and I were doing distillery/brewery tours in Dripping Springs for a cute birthday celebration. We tried Deep Eddy's but they were closed so we decided to give Frog Pong a try and we were not disappointed! The guys at the front were helpful and kind. The drinks were so affordable and flavorful, I will definitely be back.

reviews.author: Wanida S.
reviews.description: I've always wanted to stop in and check this place out. It's got a great view and their vodka and gins were tasty. They weren't overpriced and had great service. **only open on the weekends.

reviews.author: Arko G.
reviews.description: On our way to a wedding, we stopped by for a cocktail, and this was the perfect spot. We were debating between here and Deep Eddy, and we picked here for a more off the beaten path option and chill atmosphere. And we were definitely not disappointed. The staff were very helpful and welcoming and knowledgeable about their product. Outdoor seating is spacious with impressive views. Cocktails were highly affordable and very tasty. Unfortunately, tours were closed due to COVID, but we hope we can come back for tours some time soon!

reviews.author: Christina M.
reviews.description: What a nice change of pace from the better known distillery down the road. Instead of an overcrowded atmosphere with way overpriced drinks, this place is relaxing and affordable. There's a great wrap around porch to take in the landscape around you, while sipping a delicious cocktail. I definitely recommend stopping in if you're in the area!

reviews.author: Glenn R.
reviews.description: What a beautiful facility!  Stopped in for their grand opening and was amazed at such a sparkling clean, friendly place.  It's very obvious that a lot of careful thought has gone into this place. The actual distillery is incredible. The whole place is just beautiful. Even on a scorching Texas Summer day, there's a strong breeze out on the porch.  It's a very "Austin-esque" type place, down-home and friendly. Although I don't drink, my wife enjoyed a cocktail very much and we bought a bottle to take home. They had some nice lemonade and infused water for me too.  Great design of the logo, bottles and everything. Really worth stopping in if you're in the area or just feel like a nice drive from Austin.

reviews.author: Lauren G.
reviews.description: While driving into Dripping Springs for an anniversary get away we spotted this beautiful building set near 290, decided to turn in and see what it was. We weren't disappointed, Super cute place, nice patio to hang out on while sipping lovely cocktails. Really reasonably priced drinks (mixed drinks either $5 or $6 depending on choice). Has an area to play games out front, and indoor and outdoor seating.

reviews.author: Steve T.
reviews.description: They put advertising stickers on your car without permission, which is astonishing. I left the one on my trunk and added a sticker that says "sucks" under it. Unbelievable that they would do this.

reviews.author: Christiana F.
reviews.description: I stopped by after a recommendation from one of the wineries in the area. The owners were very welcoming and their drinks were fantastic! I ended up buying a bottle of gin on the way out. It was chilly and the sun was going down so we weren't able to sit outside but the view was great and seems like a fun spot during the summer.

reviews.author: Lochness P.
reviews.description: Delicious drinks! Vodka is super smooth. I recommend the Helen! And the patio with the view is beautiful!

reviews.author: Claire K.
reviews.description: Walked in was greeted and made to feel like I was in my own home. If my home was a sweet Distillery like the Frog Pond. Patio and chair were peace on Earth. With a amazing Texas Breeze. And the Gin and Tonic was just perfect. My sister got the cocktail of the day with lavender and gin and it was amazing. Color and all. I highly recommend a stop to this Local Distillery. They are A must try.

reviews.author: Carey D.
reviews.description: What a hidden gem. We started off at another well known distillery down the road and googled what else was close by and found this awesome little spot with a great view. They make small batches of vodka and gin at the distillery and make a few different drinks to try. Their porch was a great place to hang out while playing giant jenga and relaxing. I noticed cornhole as we walked in as well. We watched deer randomly wandering in the distance. The drink I had was great, a cranberry vodka fizz, so I had another. The indoor space is fairly small and the patio could fit maybe 30 people comfortably. It was not crowded at all when we were there on a Sunday afternoon. We'll go again next time we're in Austin!

reviews.author: Devin C.
reviews.description: I am very new to the Gin world, but I was truly in need of an alternative to Dark liquors. I heard about this place from a coworker and decided to take a chance. I am very happy to say that the product that they are offering, not only the liquor, is amazing. They couldn't have picked a better location to place their distillery. The hills of Texas, day or night, make relaxing on the patio with the variety of gin and vodka cocktails that much more relaxing. The bright pops of color when you venture inside of the distillery are such a delight and really made my girlfriend and I feel happy to be in such a welcoming place.   The gin was delicious and I plan to buy more bottles very soon. Don't think that my lack of praise for the vodka means that it isn't good (I am just not a fan of vodka..rough nights in college) but I definitely suggesting venturing out to this family run, local organization. You will not be disappointed.

reviews.author: Amy D.
reviews.description: Love this place!! Their gin and vodka are amazing. Their cocktails are on point. The views are phenomenal. I am never going back to deep Eddy's when frog pond is right here?!?

reviews.author: Sara B.
reviews.description: 've been to places like this before (but for primarily beer rather than wine), and I love the setup - it's super fun. You get a card that's tied to your credit card to swipe or tap and then you have access to the wine you swiped for. Then you can get as much or as little as you want. It's a great way to try and explore new wines (and mead and some margarita inspired wines). Then you can load up on your favorite (what I did), or continue exploring. Really, two great options. Also, the guy working there was nice and very helpful. I've been telling people about how much I enjoyed coming here and recommending it.  Don't park in the paid parking next to Wanderlust if you can avoid it because it's stupidly expensive. Use that money on a Lyft or more wine.

reviews.author: Yanira D.
reviews.description: Came in to buy a bottle of wine, bartender came from the back and did not greet us and told us "we're closed" although it was 9:25 and they close at 10pm on Sundays   I recommend updating the hours if you're going to close over half an hour earlier than listed

reviews.author: Chastitie A.
reviews.description: Okay, this place is super cool!  If you're into wine, and good vibes without having to feel so fancy... please come here! 56 different wines on tap. Cute inside decor with so much local art, and a bad ass patio in the back with a food truck that serves authentic Italian food! The food truck owner was extremely personable and kind! He even gave us the breakdown of the different methods of how to cook pasta in all regions of Italy.   FYI, even though this is downtown, there is a private parking lot.
